root.text: After I configured the auth environment variables, I always get an error message when starting Docker: container splice-validator-validator-1 is unhealthy. How can I determine which environment variable is configured incorrectly?

elements.text: After I configured the auth environment variables, I always get an error message when starting Docker: container splice-validator-validator-1 is unhealthy. How can I determine which environment variable is configured incorrectly?

text: Is this the reason for the startup failure?

elements.text: Is this the reason for the startup failure?
{"@timestamp":"2025-05-07T06:59:09.872Z","@version":"1","message":"Using OAuth client credentials flow with clientId='' at

","logger_name":"o.l.s.a.OAuthApi:validator=validator_backend","thread_name":"canton-env-ec-24","level":"DEBUG","level_value":10000}
{"@timestamp":"2025-05-07T06:59:10.204Z","@version":"1","message":"OAuth token response status: 401 Unauthorized","logger_name":"o.l.s.a.OAuthApi:validator=validator_backend","thread_name":"canton-env-ec-24","level":"DEBUG","level_value":10000}
The first line says shows that client id is empty, the second one shows that Auth0 responds with 401

text: How should I modify it?

elements.text: How should I modify it?

text: <https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_compose.html#configuring-authentication>

I have set all three values ​​in .env. ALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_ID is the Client ID in the Settings page of the Validator app backend application; WALLET_UI_CLIENT_ID is the Wallet web UI application, see Settings > Client ID

elements.text: I have set all three values ​​in .env. ALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_ID is the Client ID in the Settings page of the Validator app backend application; WALLET_UI_CLIENT_ID is the Wallet web UI application, see Settings > Client ID

text: <@U04KJF6UTNU> Just wanted to check if you had a chance to look

elements.text: Just wanted to check if you had a chance to look

text: `VALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_ID` is the one you need to be looking at in this case as well as its secret `VALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_SECRET`

elements.text: VALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_ID
is the one you need to be looking at in this case as well as its secret
VALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_SECRET

text: Hi Team, may I kindly ask you to add my colleagues to this channel: <mailto:a.bychkov@everstake.one|a.bychkov@everstake.one>, <mailto:y.martynenko@everstake.one|y.martynenko@everstake.one>, <mailto:z.goncharenko@everstake.one|z.goncharenko@everstake.one>. Thanks

text: Had a couple questions about the ingresses/netsec -- My main hitch/concern was about the certificate requirements. I would like to use the ACME HTTP certificate flow (since its super easy to set up and free) however it does not work with wildcard certs -- is there a hard requirement for wildcard certs/redirects or can I just enumerate all the dns records it plans on?

elements.text: Had a couple questions about the ingresses/netsec -- My main hitch/concern was about the certificate requirements. I would like to use the ACME HTTP certificate flow (since its super easy to set up and free) however it does not work with wildcard certs -- is there a hard requirement for wildcard certs/redirects or can I just enumerate all the dns records it plans on?

text: and as a follow-up im thinking about swapping out the istio sidecar setup from the docs for istio ambient with k8s gateways instead of the ingress controllers/istio gateways/virtualservices from the docs -- are the dns entries also enumerated there that I could port it over or are there other dns entries I would need to mess with?

elements.text: and as a follow-up im thinking about swapping out the istio sidecar setup from the docs for istio ambient with k8s gateways instead of the ingress controllers/istio gateways/virtualservices from the docs -- are the dns entries also enumerated there that I could port it over or are there other dns entries I would need to mess with?

text:
• let's encrypt supports wild-cards (dns-based challenge)
• wild-card is not required

elements.text: let's encrypt supports wild-cards (dns-based challenge)
wild-card is not required

text: ahh got it cool -- yeah the dns bases letsencrypt setup seemed a bit more involved (and would need to store/secure creds so it could add the dns records dynamically) so was trying to avoid that. since I don't need wildcards seems like I can dodge that bullet

elements.text: ahh got it cool -- yeah the dns bases letsencrypt setup seemed a bit more involved (and would need to store/secure creds so it could add the dns records dynamically) so was trying to avoid that. since I don't need wildcards seems like I can dodge that bullet

text: I'm not sure what the question is and I've never used ambient but Nginx ingress works well

elements.text: I'm not sure what the question is and I've never used ambient but Nginx ingress works well

text: with my setup I have a limited amount of public IP's, so by using the istio k8s gateway it lets my stuff all listen on the same natted public ip and route it internally

elements.text: with my setup I have a limited amount of public IP's, so by using the istio k8s gateway it lets my stuff all listen on the same natted public ip and route it internally

text: istio will make you cry bro. Been there.

elements.text: istio will make you cry bro. Been there.

text: in all seriousness interesting approach with ambient mode

elements.text: in all seriousness interesting approach with ambient mode

text: follow up on how you get on

elements.text: follow up on how you get on

text: sidecars work for me and i dont need more therapy

elements.text: sidecars work for me and i dont need more therapy

text: yeah been caught in the istio depression cycle of "why isnt this working theres nothing in the logs" many times -- I had the ambient stuff all set up with gateways but then saw in the docs it wanted me to have ingresses and ran into issues with what turned out to be keycloak setup, not istio

elements.text: yeah been caught in the istio depression cycle of "why isnt this working theres nothing in the logs" many times -- I had the ambient stuff all set up with gateways but then saw in the docs it wanted me to have ingresses and ran into issues with what turned out to be keycloak setup, not istio

text: I'll start moving over to ambient now that I have a bit more confidence in how the pieces interact and that there isnt for example a dynamic subdomain being used (requiring a wildcard)

elements.text: I'll start moving over to ambient now that I have a bit more confidence in how the pieces interact and that there isnt for example a dynamic subdomain being used (requiring a wildcard)

text: _I didn't realize that Ambient is another Istio mode, long time didn't touch it_

elements.text: I didn't realize that Ambient is another Istio mode, long time didn't touch it

text: yeah, ambient gets rid of the sidecars and eliminates the need for any ingress controllers, so it just needs 1 LoadBalancer service with a public IP, so I can just manually set 1 public ip to a loadbalancer service and then everything else is natted behind that

elements.text: yeah, ambient gets rid of the sidecars and eliminates the need for any ingress controllers, so it just needs 1 LoadBalancer service with a public IP, so I can just manually set 1 public ip to a loadbalancer service and then everything else is natted behind that

text: After that's working ill integrate cilium+bpf with istio and calico+bpf which should be fairly flexible for netsec

elements.text: After that's working ill integrate cilium+bpf with istio and calico+bpf which should be fairly flexible for netsec

text: sounds like you dont like to sleep

elements.text: sounds like you dont like to sleep

text: Cilium has hardware accelerated XDP support, so it _should_ be able to integrate w/ calico and let the NIC offload some of the firewall work -- im doing this on baremetal (kubeadm) with a hardware load balancer since I have unmetered bandwidth (so no cloud data transfer fees)

elements.text: Cilium has hardware accelerated XDP support, so it
should

be able to integrate w/ calico and let the NIC offload some of the firewall work -- im doing this on baremetal (kubeadm) with a hardware load balancer since I have unmetered bandwidth (so no cloud data transfer fees)

text:
>  Using OAuth client credentials flow with clientId=''
Looks like it's empty.

Would check a few things

• compose.yml
• your `.env`
Make sure it's align(no typo).

• If it looks good, it coulbd shell envrionment where you run `docker compose up` may have something that override and set VALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_ID to blank. That one take priority over.
One way to debug is you can attach a shell into the container to check env and make sure they sec.

I used docker-compose as well for the existing server/node that cannot add K8S to it and can confirm it works.

elements.text: Using OAuth client credentials flow with clientId=''

Looks like it's empty.

Would check a few things
compose.yml
your
.env
Make sure it's align(no typo).
If it looks good, it coulbd shell envrionment where you run
docker compose up
may have something that override and set VALIDATOR_AUTH_CLIENT_ID to blank. That one take priority over.

One way to debug is you can attach a shell into the container to check env and make sure they sec.

I used docker-compose as well for the existing server/node that cannot add K8S to it and can confirm it works.

text:
I use bare metal as well, it's a custom setup.

• Nginx ingress run and expose host:port. 
• Caddy handle tls and forward traffic to host:port. This is essentially an custom load balancer.
• Postgres deploy separately(not in k8s)
For my case, I also need to pin pod to a node for volume with local provisioner.

I think with bare metal where cpu/mem are cheap, there is no need to run multiple node cluster, and all the fancy of CNI maynot needed either.

The more component the more we have to looked out when upgrading with kubeadm.

If you share a cluster with multiple tenant, then it make sense with Calico and network policy. But otherwise, i like to keep it simple.

I think with bare metal where cpu/mem are cheap, there is no need to run multiple node cluster, and all the fancy of CNI maynot needed either.

The more component the more we have to looked out when upgrading with kubeadm.

If you share a cluster with multiple tenant, then it make sense with Calico and network policy. But otherwise, i like to keep it simple.

text: its true only until your single node cluster goes for an extended nap

text:
when it's down, it's likely from network or power outage of the facility. It's similarly to AZ down on cloud.

when AZ down on cloud, we cannot just quickly migrate, because volume cannot attach cross az.

So in fact, the reliability is almost seems. One thing with bare metal is we control the server, outside of the network and power, we had direct control to it and can recover from many error. we can always kvm to it, boot it to recovery mode, chroot into the partition and recover from it.

but from my exp running it in last few years, i only had a single case where the facility host my server is down and I have to restore from backup to another data center. It's a pain and the outage last 17hours for my case...

elements.text:
when it's down, it's likely from network or power outage of the facility. It's similarly to AZ down on cloud.

when AZ down on cloud, we cannot just quickly migrate, because volume cannot attach cross az.

but from my exp running it in last few years, i only had a single case where the facility host my server is down and I have to restore from backup to another data center. It's a pain and the outage last 17hours for my case...

text:
> when AZ down on cloud, we cannot just quickly migrate, because volume cannot attach cross az.
not quite - <https://cloud.google.com/kubernetes-engine/docs/concepts/persistent-volumes#regional_persistent_disks>

Agree that baremetal gives you more freedom (and better TCO). You tailor your set up how you want it rather than how a provider wants you to use it. At the end of the day it's about what works for you and risk tolerance levels. Each to their own.

elements.text: when AZ down on cloud, we cannot just quickly migrate, because volume cannot attach cross az.
not quite -

text:
Hey team, if I don’t set the `nonSvValidatorTrustSingleScan` to true in `validator-values.yaml` as part of the helm chart, my validator-app pod keeps failing the probe with a 503 error…

Looking at the logs, the only thing I can see is that it can’t connect to `<http://scan.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.tradeweb.com|scan.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.tradeweb.com>`, all other URLs is fine.  Am I missing anything or is it possible indeed for a single scan to make the whole deployment not ready?

text:
Hi Team, anyone tested the restore using Node Identities? Here is what we did in testing restore of the DevNet validator node using the Node Identities backup. Document we followed for testing the restore:
<https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_disaster_recovery.html#re-onboard-a-validator-and-recover-balances-of-all-users-it-hosts>

We have created the secret with dump file and also modified *`standalone-validator-values.yaml`* according to the document.
<https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_disaster_recovery.html#kubernetes-deployment>

While modifying *`standalone-validator-values.yaml`*, as per the document, we need to change the *`newParticipantIdentifier`* to a new value and it should be the same for *`nodeIdentifier`*  but nothing was mentioned to change *`validatorPartyHint`* . In our old configuration we gave *`validatorPartyHint`*  and *`nodeIdentifier`*  as same values.

For restore *`validatorPartyHint`* we gave kept the same value what we gave for the initial install *`chata-dev-1`*. And in the yaml we used for restore, for *`newParticipantIdentifier`* and *`nodeIdentifier`* we gave *`chata-dev-1-restore`*  and then did the restore installation. We took the backups of databases but didn't restored the databases after the install.

At this point, both the original node and restore node was running healthy. We just switched the DNS from original node to restore node and logged into the wallet. Instead of showing up old wallet *`chata-dev-1::12203dae04428d022cabccf2fca834c2e761aba5ee67e1e5ded4d7c760f527a329ba`*  a new wallet is showing up *`chata-dev-1::1220df963b700c25e1691b86c542f5876ddc9f0f9995b0210c39be5ba98a44a46221`* . But what we expected is we see the original wallet on the restore node as well with the balances i.e. *`chata-dev-1::12203dae04428d022cabccf2fca834c2e761aba5ee67e1e5ded4d7c760f527a329ba`* .  We also see the original wallet ID in the backup json file (Screenshot attached). We suspect that is because of both nodes are running with same configuration at the same time. Can anyone provide your insights on this. Thank you

• As you can see from the above both entities now have their non-zero balancers but the original party has a lot more which suggests that the migration didn't succeed during the restoration procedure.
• The screenshot you shared above shows zero balancer which is not usual if for the wallet operator user if validator is being running for some time because it is accumulating liveness rewards.

elements.text: As you can see from the above both entities now have their non-zero balancers but the original party has a lot more which suggests that the migration didn't succeed during the restoration procedure.
The screenshot you shared above shows zero balancer which is not usual if for the wallet operator user if validator is being running for some time because it is accumulating liveness rewards.
